TopicTitle: Do you have a screenshot that makes you laugh every time?

Articles.Content:
The least dramatic, most visually appealing crash landing ever

![screenshot36_zpsa0a52df5.png](http://i149.photobucket.com/albums/s59/KSPbox/screenshot36_zpsa0a52df5.png)

duna-train parachute testing gone wrong

![screenshot53_zpsf99eeade.png](http://i149.photobucket.com/albums/s59/KSPbox/screenshot53_zpsf99eeade.png)

dat atmospheric heating

![screenshot20_zps2d96093d.png](http://i149.photobucket.com/albums/s59/KSPbox/screenshot20_zps2d96093d.png)

This string of shots continues to be, and forever will be my favorite KSP related imagery.

The game crashed so hard...

![5632725be7cbbde57ccf7cc7ab046c1e_zpsfda5c2fb.jpg](http://i1273.photobucket.com/albums/y402/UU92/5632725be7cbbde57ccf7cc7ab046c1e_zpsfda5c2fb.jpg)

"Fish Taco Crater" was a flag...

And... "Joncan Kerman DEBRIS"?! Something VERY wrong happened.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-06T20:16:04Z" title="08/06/2015 08:16  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 6, 2015</time> by regex**
  
Removed inspirational image not suitable for laughing at
![3DN3r32.png](%5Bimg%5Dhttp%3A//i.imgur.com/3DN3r32.png)

Lol @ bomber comments. I -like- the ugly mashup of structural panels, because that's exactly how early Soviet bombers were constructed. The TB-1 and TB-3 along with a whole range of other early transports and bombers all had corrugated metal fuselages and appeared to be styled by designers of railroad cars. There are also no cockpits worthy of replicating the TB-3's unique 'open air' concept with the cockpit section of a cigarette boat! 

This however is my new favorite screenshot of all time - replicating a X-Com dropship flight cutscene with a KSP replica of the X-Com dropship in flight. 

![EIh99e4.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/EIh99e4.jpg)

Some of the blended wing geometry is referenced from the F-35 program.

![BLBPuzK.png](http://i.imgur.com/BLBPuzK.png)

Yep. Looks like concrete.

*Nailed it!*

![Z0VAC2J.png](http://i.imgur.com/Z0VAC2J.png)

After landing this little plane safely, I realized that the craft's SAS torque was great enough to pull it into this position. After a couple of false starts, I got the plane to balance on the nose. The result made it seem like Jeb had just suffered a rather hard landing... making it a perfect screenshot opportunity ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

-Upsilon

![OPFwTL9.png](http://i.imgur.com/OPFwTL9.png)

Did this for my 100% historically accurate Apollo simulation

> 
> [http://i.imgur.com/OPFwTL9.png](http://i.imgur.com/OPFwTL9.png)
> Did this for my 100% historically accurate Apollo simulation

The little known Apollo 10 and a half mission. ![;)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)

Really got to wonder how you guys get some of these things into orbit in the first place. 

Anyway this one always gets me.
